author: By Joseph Goldstein
title: Here Comes the Solar Eclipse
description: A total eclipse will be visible in parts of New York State today. In the city, we can expect a memorable spectacle, if the weather cooperates.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today we’ll look at a momentous day in New York: the day of the solar eclipse. Don’t forget to wear your eclipse glasses!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damon Linker
title: Why Is Biden Struggling? Because America Is Broken.
description: A majority of Americans express, and have done for years, dissatisfaction with the direction of the country.
content: Seven months away from a rematch election pitting President Biden against former President Donald Trump, the incumbent is struggling. Mr. Biden suffers from persistently low approval ratings, he barely manages to tie Mr. Trump in national head-to-head polls and he lags behind the former president in most of the swing states where the election will be decided (despite some recent modestly encouraging movement in his direction).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Vance
title: How I Tricked My Brain Into Liking Running
description: When your mind hates running even more than your body does, you have to strategize.
content: It’s common knowledge in my household that Monday at 5:55 a.m. is the worst time of the week. That’s because Monday is a running day, and I hate running.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Knvul Sheikh
title: Is That A.I. Mammogram Worth the Cost?
description: The new add-on service for breast exams can cost between $40 and $100. We asked experts to separate the sales pitch from the science.
content: Clinics around the country are starting to offer patients a new service: having their mammograms read not just by a radiologist, but also by an artificial intelligence model. The hospitals and companies that provide these tools tout their ability to speed the work of radiologists and detect cancer earlier than standard mammograms alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: U.N. Inspectors Say Nuclear Plant in Ukraine Was Struck by Drones
description: The watchdog agency did not attribute blame, but its head said the strikes at the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant “significantly increase the risk of a major nuclear accident.”
content: The head of the United Nations nuclear watchdog agency has condemned drone strikes at the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant, saying “such reckless attacks significantly increase the risk of a major nuclear accident and must be stopped immediately.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford and Claire Fahy
title: Housing, Crime, Climate: The Big Questions Holding Up New York’s Budget
description: New York lawmakers are moving closer to a deal on a state budget, but a slew of obstacles remain, including the timing of Monday’s total eclipse.
content: For those who say that an on-time budget in New York State is about as likely as a solar eclipse, the odds on an eclipse are about to improve.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Baker
title: Skip the Traffic: Commuters Turn to Ferries to Get Around
description: Ferry ridership took a hit during the pandemic. But new terminals, additional routes and faster, smaller boats are driving a new era of water transportation and development.
content: As remote work reshapes the way people live and travel around cities, Americans are taking to the waterways not only as part of their commute but also as part of their daily lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Trussoni
title: Leigh Bardugo’s Latest Travels to Renaissance Spain
description: In “The Familiar,” the blockbuster fantasist conjures a world of mystical intrigue and romance.
content: For those unacquainted with Catholic demonology, a familiar, or “familiar spirit,” as the phrase shows up in the Bible, is an otherworldly creature indentured to a master, usually whoever’s summoned it — a witch or necromancer or, in the case of Aladdin, a lucky rube who finds a bottle in need of a shine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz and Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Man Kills 2, Then Himself, at Las Vegas Law Office
description: The police said that the shooting had happened during a deposition in a child custody case.
content: A man fatally shot two people at a Las Vegas law office on Monday morning during a deposition in a child custody case, then killed himself, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Kornei
title: They Came From Outer Space. Now, They’re Going Into Hiding.
description: Rising temperatures in Antarctica are making meteorites sink out of view before researchers can collect them.
content: If you’re looking for meteorites, here’s a tip: Go south. All the way south. And do it soon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Moskin
title: An Easy Mac and Cheese Worth Cheering
description: Genevieve Ko’s simple stovetop version comes together with just five ingredients.
content: Welcome to the week! I’m filling in for Melissa and just as excited as she is for spring’s fresh peas and picnics. But those come around every year, and a new New York Times Cooking recipe for macaroni and cheese is a special event. Joining Millie Peartree’s Southern-style casserole, Eric Kim’s Stouffer’s copycat, and my so-weird-that-it-works recipe, Genevieve Ko’s new stovetop version is our first to bear the label “easy,” and it’s also creamy, classic and made from just five scratch ingredients. Welcome to the dance floor!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquín
title: In California, Half an Eclipse Is Better Than None
description: Californians in the Bay Area and in Southern California braced for a favorable view of the partial eclipse as clouds dissipated on Monday morning.
content: The sun, or at least most of it, will keep shining in California during the eclipse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Col. Ralph Puckett Jr., Belated Medal of Honor Winner, Dies at 97
description: One of the Army’s most highly decorated servicemen, he received the military’s supreme tribute for valor, for his actions in the Korean War — 71 years after the fact.
content: Col. Ralph Puckett Jr., who was belatedly awarded the Medal of Honor in May 2021 for his exploits seven decades earlier, commanding vastly outnumbered Army Rangers in a battle with Communist Chinese troops during the Korean War, died on Monday at his home in Columbus, Ga. One of the most highly decorated servicemen in the history of the Army, he was 97.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: ‘Eureka Day’ and Sondheim Revue Join Broadway’s Next Season
description: Bernadette Peters and Lea Salonga will star in Sondheim’s “Old Friends” in Manhattan Theater Club’s Broadway season, which also includes “Eureka Day.”
content: Manhattan Theater Club, one of the four nonprofit organizations that operate houses on Broadway, is planning to stage a vaccination comedy called “Eureka Day” and the Sondheim revue “Old Friends” at its Samuel J. Friedman Theater next season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: France Bracing for Cyberattacks During Summer Olympics
description: French officials are visiting Washington for cybersecurity consultations as President Emmanuel Macron predicts Moscow will try to target the Games.
content: The Summer Olympics and tensions over the war in Ukraine are likely to make Paris a tempting target for a variety of hacking attempts, including from adversarial countries, France’s top cybersecurity official said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: A Protest Set to Banjo: Jamar Roberts’s Dance for Hard Times
description: “We the People,” Roberts’s first dance for the Martha Graham Dance Company, finds the rage and resistance hidden in an upbeat score by Rhiannon Giddens.
content: “This isn’t fun.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof and Jillian Weinberger
title: Deepfake Porn Sites Used Her Image. She’s Fighting Back.
description: Nicholas Kristof on why tech companies aren’t powerless over the spread of deepfake porn.
content: Deepfakes — A.I.-generated imagery that often uses real people’s faces and identities — have proliferated online. A recent study found that 98 percent of deepfake videos online are pornographic, and 99 percent of those target women and girls. The activist and survivor Breeze Liu’s image was used by multiple sites. In this audio essay, she tells her story to the columnist Nicholas Kristof. They argue that search engines such as Google and Bing have the power to combat the scourge of deepfake pornography. “Google can be socially responsible when it wants to be,” Kristof explains. “But in this case, it just seems to be completely indifferent to companies that go out of their way to humiliate women and girls and make money off it.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Why a Savory English Pastry Is Beloved in a California Town
description: The popularity of the Cornish pasty, a meat pie eaten by hand like a sandwich, is a legacy of the gold rush.
content: In a charming former mining town in the Sierra Nevada foothills, you can taste pieces of California history dating back nearly 175 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Yellen Sees ‘More Work to Do’ as China Talks End With No Breakthrough
description: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen was warmly received in China, but it was evident that the level of trust between the two sides does not run deep.
content: Four days of top-level economic meetings between the United States and China concluded in Beijing on Monday with no major breakthrough, but the world’s two largest economies agreed to hold more discussions to address rising friction over trade, investment and national security.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Danny Hakim
title: Georgia Trump Prosecutor Urges Appeals Court to Decline Disqualification Case
description: The prosecutor, Fani Willis, defended a judge’s recent ruling that she could continue leading the election interference case against Donald J. Trump.
content: Fani T. Willis, the district attorney of Fulton County, Ga., filed a motion on Monday seeking to block an appeal of a ruling last month allowing her to continue leading the state election interference case against former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: The Invasive-Species Debate Is Not Always Simple
description: Where they are welcomed, wild creatures can find a way to make use of nearly everything.
content: Where starlings are concerned, I thought my heart was a stone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenn Pelly
title: ‘Is She Sure?’ How the Breeders Joined Olivia Rodrigo’s Guts Tour.
description: The ’90s alt-rock icons hit the Madison Square Garden stage for the first time Friday night, after the 21-year-old pop star invited them to join her on the road.
content: Olivia Rodrigo remembers her life in two parts: before she heard the Breeders’ “Cannonball,” and after, she told the crowd at Madison Square Garden on Friday night, when her Guts World Tour arrived in New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calum Marsh
title: To Become Prince Andrew, He Needed More Than False Teeth
description: In the feature “Scoop,” streaming on Netflix, Rufus Sewell plays the disgraced royal blundering through a 2019 BBC interview.
content: Before filming started on “Scoop,” a Netflix feature about Prince Andrew’s notoriously misjudged 2019 interview on the BBC, the actor Rufus Sewell, who stars as the disgraced royal, turned up on set to shoot a few photographs that would appear in the background. Loaded with makeup and prosthetics, including false teeth and a feathery wig, Sewell felt leaden and self-conscious, he said, fearful that his impersonation would slip into parody.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Glatsky
title: A Diplomatic Spat in Ecuador May Lift Its President’s Political Fortunes
description: Analysts believe that President Daniel Noboa’s re-election hopes are what motivated the arrest of an Ecuadorean politician taking refuge at the Mexican Embassy.
content: Ecuador’s decision to send police officers into the Mexican Embassy to arrest a politician who had taken refuge there inflamed tensions between two countries that were already at odds, but it may prove a political boon for the Ecuadorean president.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Gazing at the Sky, Awaiting a Moment of Awe
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, April 7, 2024.
content: “Awe is an emotion when you encounter things you don’t understand. Wonder follows experiences of awe because you want to explain the mystery of it.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: Putting Abortion Question to Florida Voters Is Unlikely to End Court Fights
description: Though the Florida Supreme Court allowed a ballot question on expanding abortion rights, it also laid out a way for anti-abortion groups to challenge such an expansion.
content: Abortion-rights supporters celebrated last week when the Florida Supreme Court said voters could decide this fall whether to approve a state constitutional amendment protecting and expanding abortion rights in Florida. But the court also laid out a road map for anti-abortion groups to challenge any expansion, by raising the prospect of “fetal personhood.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris
title: Here Are the Most Targeted Books of 2023
description: Amid a nationwide surge in book bans, memoirs and novels that deal with the experiences of L.G.B.T.Q. people or explore race received the most challenges.
content: The most challenged books in the United States in 2023 continued to focus on the experiences of L.G.B.T.Q. people or explore themes of race, according to a report released Monday by the American Library Association.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Geordon Wollner
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Grey Gardens’ and Billy Joel in Concert
description: TCM airs the cult classic 1975 documentary, and Joel airs his first broadcast concert at Madison Square Garden.
content: For those who still haven’t cut the cord, here is a selection of cable and network TV shows, movies and specials that broadcast this week, April 8-14. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: Review: ‘Curb Your Enthusiasm’ Wraps Up in Familiar Fashion
description: Larry David’s HBO comedy ended on Sunday after 12 seasons. Longtime fans might have noticed similarities with a certain earlier sitcom.
content: After 12 seasons, spread across 25 years, the HBO comedy staple “Curb Your Enthusiasm” ends with an episode that sees Larry David put on trial. Witness after witness testifies to Larry’s lifetime of selfish and antisocial behavior. The jury finds him guilty, of course.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: Israel’s Account of Attack on Aid Convoy Raises Wider Legal Questions, Experts Say
description: The events that led to the deaths of seven World Central Kitchen workers suggest that there could be problems with the protocols used by the Israeli military, according to legal experts and aid organizations.
content: Israel’s account of its attack on a World Central Kitchen convoy raises significant legal questions even if the strike was the result of a series of mistakes, experts say.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: April 8, 2024
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, April 8, 2024.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joanne Silberner
title: Large Scientific Review Confirms the Benefits of Physical Touch
description: Premature babies especially benefited from skin-to-skin contact, and women tended to respond more strongly than men did.
content: A hug, a handshake, a therapeutic massage. A newborn lying on a mother’s bare chest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $900,000 Homes in California
description: A 1929 Spanish-style house in Riverside, a two-bedroom condominium in Pasadena and a midcentury ranch house in Long Beach.
content: This house is at the base of Mount Rubidoux, in a quiet neighborhood about five minutes from the center of the city. The sellers, who bought and renovated it last year, retained original elements wherever possible, including the quarter-sawn oak floors and the casement windows, which were removed, restored and reinstalled. The home is less than a mile from a community garden, a park with a playground and a trail winding up the mountain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Democratic Group Aims to Spend Heavily in Wisconsin Legislative Races
description: After Wisconsin’s Supreme Court ordered new legislative maps, Democrats are gearing up to try to flip the State Assembly — and give President Biden a boost.
content: The States Project, a deep-pocketed outside group focused exclusively on state legislatures, is adding the Wisconsin State Assembly to its 2024 plans, a clear sign that Democrats are growing bullish on an opportunity to flip the chamber after the State Supreme Court ordered new maps to be drawn this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Armando Tivane and Emma Bubola
title: Nearly 100 Die After Overloaded Boat Sinks Off Coast of Mozambique
description: Some of the victims were en route to a fair and others were fleeing for fear of being affected by a cholera outbreak, a local official said.
content: Nearly 100 people died and more than a dozen were missing after an overcrowded boat sank off the coast of Mozambique, the local authorities said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King
title: Leading Anti-Abortion Group Says It Is ‘Deeply Disappointed’ in Trump’s Comments
description: The president of Susan B. Anthony Pro-Life America said she was “deeply disappointed” in Donald J. Trump’s position that states should decide abortion rights.
content: After former President Donald J. Trump announced his position that abortion rights should be decided by individual states, the leading anti-abortion group supporting Republican candidates said his stance fell short.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Bernstein and Callie Holtermann
title: Is the Era of ‘Brozempic’ Upon Us?
description: Some telehealth start-ups are playing up masculine stereotypes to market medications that have been more widely associated with women.
content: A grinning golfer with a modest belly, admiring a drive. A silver fox in a suit jacket, enjoying a glass of wine as a beautiful woman gazes into his eyes. A bearded father, cooking for his children in a sun-dappled kitchen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jess Bidgood
title: College Towns Usually Lift Democrats. Is the Picture More Complicated in 2024?
description: An enthusiasm gap among young voters and anger on campuses over Gaza has some Democrats wary.
content: If you want to be the president, you should probably win Wisconsin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Announces Student Debt Relief for Millions in Swing-State Pitch
description: During an appearance in Wisconsin, President Biden said 10 million borrowers could see debt relief of at least $5,000. The plan could help rally support among young voters.
content: President Biden on Monday announced a large-scale effort to help pay off federal student loans for tens of millions of American borrowers, seeking an election-year boost by returning to a 2020 campaign promise that was blocked by the Supreme Court last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Everything Is Getting Very Familiar
description: Avert your eyes.
content: Bret Stephens: Good news, bad news, Gail. The economy added just over 300,000 new jobs last month, which gives Joe Biden something to brag about. But illegal immigration is now the No. 1 concern for voters, according to a story in The Wall Street Journal, and in one February poll 65 percent of Americans disapproved of Biden’s handling of the border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Katie Rogers
title: Biden Campaign Ad Blames Trump for Near-Death of Woman Who Was Denied Abortion
description: The ad encapsulates the strategy by the president’s campaign to seize on anger about the Supreme Court’s 2022 decision to overturn Roe v. Wade.
content: President Biden’s re-election campaign on Monday released a searing campaign ad blaming former President Donald J. Trump for the near-death of a Texas woman who suffered infections after she was denied an abortion following a miscarriage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Rauch and Peter Wehner
title: There Is a Way Out of MAGA Domination
description: What America needs is a counterestablishment dedicated to recapturing the G.O.P. from the outside.
content: A few weeks ago, Mike Pence did what no other vice president in the modern era has done: He refused to endorse the re-election of the president under whom he served. When it comes to alumni of Donald Trump’s administration, Mr. Pence is hardly alone; the list of high-ranking officials who worked for Mr. Trump and have implied or outright stated that they can’t support their former boss under any circumstances has grown to an astonishing length.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Protess, Jonah E. Bromwich and William K. Rashbaum
title: Appeals Court Denies Another Trump Attempt to Delay Trial
description: Donald J. Trump’s lawyers sought to pause his Manhattan criminal trial as they argued that it should be moved, but a judge rejected their appeal.
content: One week before Donald J. Trump is set to face a criminal trial in Manhattan, an appeals court judge on Monday rejected his effort to pause the case and move it to a different location.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Morgan Wallen Arrested, Accused of Throwing a Chair From a Bar Roof
description: The country superstar faces charges of reckless endangerment and disorderly conduct after the incident in Nashville on Sunday night.
content: The country singer Morgan Wallen was arrested early Monday in Nashville on charges of reckless endangerment and disorderly conduct, after he was accused of throwing a chair from the roof of a downtown bar, according to reports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz and Thalíe Ponce
title: Ex-Ecuadorean Vice President, Arrested at Mexican Embassy, Is Hospitalized
description: The former vice president, Jorge Glas, had taken pills, the police said, and was taken to a hospital. He had taken refuge at the embassy after being accused of corruption.
content: Authorities found a former Ecuadorean vice president, Jorge Glas, in a “deep self-induced coma” in jail on Monday, just days after he was captured by the police in a dramatic arrest inside the Mexican embassy in Quito.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deborah Blum
title: The Two Men Who Wanted to Categorize ‘Every Living Thing’ on Earth
description: Jason Roberts tells the story of the scholars who tried to taxonomize the world.
content: A professor asks a student to go on a plant-collecting trip, a perilous journey from Sweden to Suriname in 1754. The devoted student agrees, which means months tossed about on a wooden ship while chased by a simmering fever. When the student returns, he still shows hints of delirium, declaring that one of his specimens can produce a harvest of pearls, refusing to turn over any of his treasures to his mentor. What’s a plant-obsessed professor to do?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas
title: Democrats in Pennsylvania Urge Biden to Branch Out Beyond Philadelphia
description: Vice President Kamala Harris will stop in the city on Monday to promote efforts to forgive student debt. Some local officials are calling for greater outreach in more rural areas.
content: President Biden loves Philadelphia. And he loves campaigning there, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Jensen
title: After I Lost My Son, I Realized I Needed to Stop Looking for Closure
description: Must grief for the climate diminish you, or can it do the opposite?
content: Four years ago, I got the news that every parent dreads.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: L.A. Times Names Terry Tang as Executive Editor
description: Ms. Tang, who had been running the news organization on an interim basis since January, takes charge at a turbulent time for the publication.
content: The Los Angeles Times on Monday named Terry Tang as its permanent executive editor, making her the first woman to lead the paper’s newsroom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: cachet
description: This word has appeared in 88 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word cachet has appeared in 88 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Feb. 28 in “Nepo Babies Crowd the Runways” by Elizabeth Paton:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Kodé
title: When Your Boss Is Your Landlord
description: A Brooklyn hospital is trying to evict employees and retirees from staff housing, as it struggles financially, but tenants fear they will now be homeless in an unaffordable city.
content: A five-minute walk to work and around $600 a month in rent was hard to pass up in 1990.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anjali Huynh
title: Pence Attacks Trump’s Abortion Statement as a ‘Slap in the Face’
description: Mike Pence, an evangelical Christian who embraced abortion restrictions at the federal level shortly after Roe was overturned, called Mr. Trump’s statement a “retreat” on the matter.
content: Former Vice President Mike Pence delivered a scathing rebuke to former President Donald J. Trump’s announcement on Monday that he thought abortion rights should be left to the states, calling Mr. Trump’s video statement a “slap in the face” to the anti-abortion voters who supported him in 2016 and 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: The Economic Luminary Who Loved Solar Eclipses
description: Inspired by science, William Stanley Jevons strove to make economics a more rigorous field.
content: In 1857, William Stanley Jevons was 22 years old and was working as an assayer for the Sidney Mint. Two eclipses passed over Australia that year, and Jevons enthusiastically tracked both. “After sleepless night got up about 3:30 and started to Bellevue Hill in dark,” he wrote in his diary about one, which must have happened shortly after dawn. “About 5 a.m. commenced observations concerning eclipse.” (After the eclipse, he went to work, wrote a detailed report on it for a local newspaper, had tea with the mint’s chief engineer and in the evening caught a performance of “Much Ado About Nothing.”)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mathilde Ross
title: Anxious Parents Are the Ones Who Need Help
description: Today’s parents are suffering from anxiety about their children’s anxiety, and it’s not easy to persuade them that all is OK.
content: This month, across the country, a new cohort of students is being accepted into colleges. And, if recent trends continue, the start of the new school year will kick off another record-breaking season for anxiety on campus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Eckinger
title: What Solar Eclipse-Gazing Has Looked Like for the Past 2 Centuries
description: Millions of people on Monday will continue the tradition of experiencing and capturing solar eclipses, a pursuit that has spawned a lot of unusual gear.
content: For centuries, people have been clamoring to glimpse solar eclipses. From astronomers with custom-built photographic equipment to groups huddled together with special glasses, this spectacle has captivated the human imagination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Baruch College, an Upward-Mobility Machine
description: The New York school is praised as a model college in a new report on diversity in higher education.
content: City College of New York often serves as a nostalgic symbol of American higher education’s past. The college did not charge tuition for decades, and its students, many of them poor, went on to become Nobel laureates, chief executives, civil rights leaders and more. By contrast, higher education today can seem both less accessible and less rigorous.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Trump Says Abortion Will Be Left to the States. Don’t Believe Him.
description: His allies are planning to resurrect and enforce the 19th-century Comstock Act.
content: When Donald Trump was asked about the recent Florida Supreme Court decision upholding his adopted state’s abortion ban, he promised that he would announce where he stands this week, a sign of how tricky the politics of reproductive rights have become for the man who did more than any other to roll them back. Sure enough, on Monday, he unveiled his latest position in a video statement that attempted to thread the needle between his anti-abortion base and the majority of Americans who want abortion to be legal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: J. Cole Apologizes for Kendrick Lamar Diss Track
description: J. Cole also vowed to update the track, “7 Minute Drill,” or remove it from streaming services after it was featured on his new album, “Might Delete Later.”
content: The rapper J. Cole apologized on Sunday for releasing a diss track about Kendrick Lamar, saying he felt “terrible” and vowing to update the song or remove it from streaming services.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa Wilkinson
title: When Tom Ripley Stares Into the Mirror, He Sees Us
description: In the new series and in five previous movies, the character serves as a blank slate to examine the mores and concerns of the time.
content: Tom Ripley’s background is always sketchy. Patricia Highsmith provides only a few rudimentary details in the first few chapters of “The Talented Mr. Ripley,” her 1955 novel that kicked off a series of five books about the elusive con artist. Tom lives in New York, in near-destitute circumstances. He has some friends — acquaintances, really — whom he hates, mentally labeling them “the riffraff, the vulgarians, the slobs.” He wants nothing more than to be rid of them, and after the first few chapters, he succeeds. He receives money from an aunt in Boston; she raised him after his parents drowned in the harbor there. He hates her, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Li Yuan
title: What Chinese Outrage Over ‘3 Body Problem’ Says About China
description: The Netflix series showcases one of the country’s most successful works of culture. Instead of demonstrating pride, social media is condemning it.
content: The first five minutes of the Netflix series “3 Body Problem” were hard to watch.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Gazans Turn to a Wild Plant to Combat Wartime Hunger
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, April 8, 2024.
content: “People survived the darkest chapters of the war on khobeza alone.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Ex-Officials Urge Curbing Presidential Power to Deploy Troops on U.S. Soil
description: The bipartisan group says the point is not about Donald J. Trump’s desire to invoke the Insurrection Act, but rather that current law gives all presidents too much unfettered power.
content: A bipartisan group of former senior national security and legal officials, including veterans of the Trump administration, are urging lawmakers to impose new limits on a president’s power to deploy federal troops on domestic soil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nico Grant
title: Google to Tone Down Message Board After Employees Feud Over War in Gaza
description: The company is making changes to a popular message board called Memegen that some employees say sounds a lot like censorship.
content: For nearly 14 years, an online message board called Memegen has served as a virtual water cooler for Google employees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Dyer
title: Sometimes, to Make an Electric Car Better, You’ve Got to Make It a Little Worse
description: Sales of electric vehicles are sagging in part because they’re so dull to drive compared with their gas counterparts.
content: We’re at an inflection point in electric-car optimism. Over the past few years, as electric vehicle sales increased substantially and car companies announced an onslaught of new battery-powered models, it seemed that electric cars were a near-term inevitability. But for all the heady promise, E.V. enthusiasm seems to be cooling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Ngo and Don Clark
title: TSMC Will Receive $6.6 Billion to Bolster U.S. Chip Manufacturing
description: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company plans to build an additional factory and upgrade another planned facility in Phoenix with the federal grants.
content: The Biden administration will award up to $6.6 billion in grants to Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, the leading maker of the most advanced microchips, in a bid to bring some of the most cutting-edge semiconductor technology to the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Singer
title: Maryland Passes 2 Major Privacy Bills, Despite Tech Industry Pushback
description: One bill would require apps like Instagram and TikTok to prioritize young people’s safety, and the other would restrict the collection of consumer data.
content: The Maryland legislature this weekend passed two sweeping privacy bills that aim to restrict how powerful tech platforms can harvest and use the personal data of consumers and young people — despite strong objections from industry trade groups representing giants like Amazon, Google and Meta.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Singer
title: Teen Girls Confront an Epidemic of Deepfake Nudes in Schools
description: Using artificial intelligence, middle and high school students have fabricated explicit images of female classmates and shared the doctored pictures.
content: Westfield Public Schools held a regular board meeting in late March at the local high school, a red brick complex in Westfield, N.J., with a scoreboard outside proudly welcoming visitors to the “Home of the Blue Devils” sports teams.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Protess, Jesse McKinley, Kate Christobek and William K. Rashbaum
title: Judge in Trump Criminal Case Braces for Glare of Unprecedented Trial
description: Juan Merchan, a target of Donald J. Trump’s wrath, has years of experience on the Manhattan bench but will face a uniquely challenging defendant next week.
content: Inside a dreary Lower Manhattan courtroom on a recent Wednesday, Justice Juan M. Merchan convened a special session for people with mental health troubles who had landed in legal jeopardy. He calmly counseled them, praised any signs of progress and shook the hand of one man who, thanks to medication, had turned his life around.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: Jonathan Majors Avoids Jail Time for Assault Conviction
description: Mr. Majors, a rising movie star before his conviction in December, was sentenced to a domestic violence program for assaulting an ex-girlfriend last year.
content: Jonathan Majors, a rising movie star who was found guilty last year of assaulting and harassing his then-girlfriend, Grace Jabbari, was sentenced in Manhattan Criminal Court on Monday to 52 weeks of domestic violence programming, to take place in Los Angeles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller and Josh Katz
title: What Researchers Discovered When They Sent 80,000 Fake Résumés to U.S. Jobs
description: Some companies discriminated against Black applicants much more than others, and H.R. practices made a big difference.
content: A group of economists recently performed an experiment on around 100 of the largest companies in the country, applying for jobs using made-up résumés with equivalent qualifications but different personal characteristics. They changed applicants’ names to suggest that they were white or Black, and male or female — Latisha or Amy, Lamar or Adam.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Beyoncé’s ‘Cowboy Carter’ Opens at No. 1 With the Year’s Biggest Sales
description: The pop superstar’s new album also reigns on Billboard’s Top Country Albums chart, the first time a Black woman has led that tally in its 60-year history.
content: Beyoncé’s genre-bending “Cowboy Carter” has become her eighth No. 1 album, opening with the biggest sales of any release so far this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Sydney Harper, Alex Stern, Will Reid, Jessica Cheung, Devon Taylor, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano, Elisheba Ittoop, Corey Schreppel and Chris Wood
title: The Eclipse Chaser
description: As millions of Americans prepare to see a total solar eclipse, a retired astrophysicist known as “Mr. Eclipse,” discusses the celestial phenomenon.
content: Today, millions of Americans will have the opportunity to see a rare total solar eclipse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King
title: Biden and Other Democrats Tie Trump to Limits on Abortion Rights
description: The former president said he supported leaving abortion decisions to states, but political opponents say he bears responsibility for any curbs enacted.
content: Democrats, seeking to tie abortion restrictions to former President Donald J. Trump and Republicans, again laid the blame for limits on reproductive rights at Mr. Trump’s feet, saying the former president’s statement on Monday calling for abortion restrictions to be decided by states was part of a pattern of “extreme” lawmaking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Protess, Kate Christobek and Jonah E. Bromwich
title: What to Know About the Trial Donald Trump Faces in Manhattan
description: Prosecutors accused Donald Trump of falsifying business records to cover up a sex scandal. It will be the first criminal trial of a former president.
content: In just one week, Donald J. Trump will go on trial in Manhattan — the first former U.S. president to be criminally prosecuted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Zornosa
title: In an Election Year, ‘Suffs’ Takes a Political Battle to Broadway
description: As Shaina Taub’s musical opens, the show’s team members, including Hillary Clinton, say they’re ready to give the women’s suffrage movement a bigger platform.
content: Shaina Taub was ready to watch Hillary Clinton win in November 2016. She had been at Harvard, doing research for an ambitious musical about the women’s suffrage movement, and was swept up in what felt like the inevitable: a woman elected president of the United States. Taub had traveled to New York City from Cambridge for election night, eager to cheer on Clinton, whom she had phone banked for.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter
title: Anthony Insolia, Who Led the Expansion of Newsday, Dies at 98
description: The Long Island paper won seven Pulitzer Prizes during his tenure, and he was a top editor for the Arizona Project, which investigated a reporter’s murder.
content: Anthony Insolia, a down-to-earth former editor of Newsday who presided over that Long Island newspaper’s expansion and several big investigative projects, died on Saturday in Philadelphia. He was 98.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: Delmore Schwartz’s Poems Are Like Salt Flicked on the World
description: A new omnibus compiles the poet’s books and unpublished work, including his two-part autobiographical masterpiece, “Genesis.”
content: Come with me, down the rabbit hole that is the life and work of the Brooklyn-born poet Delmore Schwartz (1913-66). There are two primary portals into Delmore World. Neither involves his own verse. Reading about Schwartz is more invigorating than reading him, or so I have long thought. He was so intense and unbuttoned that he inspired two of the best books of the second half of the 20th century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Salam
title: The Best True Crime to Stream: Scams, Schemes and Costly Lies
description: Four picks across television, film and podcast that depict the art of the con.
content: There are so many true crime offerings dedicated to scams, frauds and con artists that it can be overwhelming. Many of these stories are astonishing and worthy of attention, whether the deceptions are financial, medical, romantic or otherwise. Often most surprising is how relatively painless it seems to lay such traps, and how many people, regardless of personal circumstances, take the bait.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green
title: What to Know About Biden’s New Student Debt Relief Plan
description: The proposal would affect nearly 30 million people and would target groups that have had hardships in repaying their loans.
content: President Biden released details on Monday of his new student loan debt forgiveness plan for nearly 30 million borrowers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King and Micah Green
title: How Abortion, and I.V.F., Flipped an Alabama State House Seat
description: Marilyn Lands’s victory in a special election provided an early blueprint for Democrats who are eager to make reproductive rights central to their campaigns.
content: When Marilyn Lands, a Democrat, won an election last month for a northern Alabama State House district that Republicans had held for more than two decades, she stretched the political power of reproductive rights into the edges of Appalachia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pamela Paul
title: A Moment of Unity, on Earth as in Space
description: As totality approached, it felt, for a change, like we were all rooting for the same team.
content: Maybe it takes an extraterrestrial event to bring this shredded country together. For a phenomenon that traversed the country from the contentious southern border to the far reaches of New England, Monday’s eclipse attracted remarkably few conspiracy theories or accusations. From where I stood, in Buffalo, the major threat to the moment was a forecast of heavy clouds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frances Robles
title: For Nicaragua, International Case Against Germany Is Déjà Vu
description: Nicaragua’s accusation against Germany in the International Court of Justice comes 40 years after the country filed a claim against the United States in the same court.
content: For Nicaragua’s representative to the International Court of Justice, this week’s hearing before the World Court was a case of déjà vu.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiba Yazbek
title: Palestinians Return to an Unrecognizable City After Israelis Withdraw
description: “You build a home corner by corner, stone by stone,” said one man who came back to Khan Younis. “And in the end, with a press of a button, it is reduced to rubble.”
content: The withdrawal of Israeli ground troops from southern Gaza over the weekend allowed some Palestinians to return to the city of Khan Younis and check on their homes. But in the aftermath of a fierce, monthslong battle and Israeli bombings, some found only destruction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Guns, Machetes and Illness: The Perils of Running the Length of Africa
description: Russ Cook of Britain overcame danger in a year of running from South Africa to Tunisia.
content: Going for a run can get a bit more difficult when it lasts for a year and is complicated by robbery, illness and men with machetes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: She Lied, Cheated and Stole. Then She Wrote a Book About It.
description: In her buzzy memoir, “Sociopath,” Patric Gagne shows herself more committed to revel in her naughtiness than to demystify the condition.
content: That Patric Gagne is a sociopath isn’t news. She wrote about it for The New York Times’s Modern Love column, which led to a deal for a book that I have just hurled across the room like a discus, and an extensive pre-publication interview with my colleague David Marchese.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz and Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Four Takeaways From the Vatican’s Document on Human Dignity
description: The document restated the Roman Catholic Church’s rejection of abortion, gender fluidity and transition surgery.
content: The document issued on Monday by the Vatican puts human dignity at the center of Catholic life, but in doing so, it broaches some of the most difficult and sensitive social issues, those that Pope Francis has spent his papacy avoiding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: J Street Seeks a Middle Path on Gaza. Is That Possible Anymore?
description: The center-left Jewish lobby group has lost some staff members and donors who worry the organization has not been quick enough to call for a cease-fire and is alienating younger generations.
content: Over the last five years, the Jewish political advocacy group J Street reached new heights of influence. The center-left lobby, whose slogan upon its founding in 2008 was “pro-Israel, pro-peace,” saw five Democratic presidential candidates stump at its 2019 convention. It helped persuade 48 congressional Democrats to back a 2021 bill that would have pressured Israel to further a two-state solution. In 2022, J Street had its best fund-raising year up to that point, a spokesman confirmed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Good Economy, Negative Vibes: The Story Continues
description: The economy is in good shape. Why are so many Americans still saying it’s bad?
content: When it comes to economic news, we’ve had so much winning that we’ve gotten tired of winning, or at any rate blasé about it. Last week, we got another terrific employment report — job growth for 39 straight months — and it feels as if hardly anyone noticed. In particular, it’s not clear whether the good news will dent the still widespread but false narrative that President Biden is presiding over a bad economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melena Ryzik
title: ‘Curb’ Finale Shows ‘Larry’s Never Learned His Lesson’
description: In an interview, Jeff Schaffer and Susie Essman discuss why Larry David revived the polarizing “Seinfeld” finale. “We know what you thought of that, and we don’t care,” Schaffer said.
content: With a parade of callbacks and a twist a quarter-century in the making, “Curb Your Enthusiasm,” the HBO series starring Larry David as a heightened version of himself, ended its 20-plus-year run on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Prosecutors Defend Case Against Alec Baldwin in ‘Rust’ Shooting
description: As the actor’s defense team seeks the dismissal of the involuntary manslaughter indictment, the prosecution detailed some of the factors that led it to seek charges.
content: Prosecutors in New Mexico defended their handling of the involuntary manslaughter case against Alec Baldwin on Friday, filing court papers in which they accused the actor of negligently failing to make sure the gun he was handed before the fatal “Rust” shooting was not loaded with live ammunition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Jamie Dimon Issues an Economic Warning
description: The JPMorgan Chase chief executive used his annual letter to shareholders to flag higher-for-longer inflation, uncertain growth prospects and widening political divisions.
content: Jamie Dimon’s annual letter to JPMorgan Chase shareholders has just been published. The widely read note offers a glimpse of his views on not just business, but the economy at a “pivotal moment for America and the free world,” with deep divisions at home and global uncertainty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 302
description: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Arkansas Braces for Flood of Tourists During Total Solar Eclipse
description: The state has miles of rugged terrain and an array of state parks, but it does not have a major professional sports team. Officials have struggled to think of an event comparable to the eclipse.
content: The email landed in the inbox of Dave Parker, an Arkansas government employee, in 2021: Hey, we’ve got this eclipse coming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: The North American Total Solar Eclipse Is Here. Are You Watching?
description: A place for students to share their thoughts on this cosmic event, whether they are observing in person or watching from afar.
content: Today, April 8, a total solar eclipse will trace a path through North America from the west coast of Mexico to the east coast of Canada. Will you be watching?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Israeli Opposition Leader Calls for Close Ties With U.S. in Visit
description: In the wake of President Biden’s recent warning to Israel to stop the killing of civilians in Gaza, Yair Lapid said the two countries “need to maintain this friendship.”
content: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken met on Monday with Israel’s opposition leader, Yair Lapid, who reaffirmed the underlying U.S.-Israel bond despite tensions between President Biden and Mr. Lapid’s chief political rival, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Jenna Russell, Ian Stewart, Jessica Metzger and James Shield
title: Israel’s Latest Troop Withdrawal, and the Problem With American Bridges
description: Plus, is it eclipse weather?
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Tayi Tibble, Maori Poet and ‘It Girl’, Trusts the Wisdom of Her Ancestors
description: Tibble, 28, has been hailed as the fresh, funny and immensely skilled voice of a generation.
content: As an Indigenous New Zealander, the poet Tayi Tibble is descended from expert Polynesian navigators who traversed thousands of miles of Pacific Ocean. When disoriented by self-doubt or impostor syndrome, she relies on their wisdom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Eavis
title: How Thin Air and Summer Snow Can Heal the Soul
description: Last July, a recently divorced writer who had found solace in hiking took on a towering challenge: Mount Whitney, the highest peak in the lower 48 states.
content: A brutish granite ridge soared above us in the moonlight. The snow that should not have been there in July seemed to go on forever. We were already short of breath, and weirdly, there were almost no other hikers. Even though I had trained for this, I felt stupidly out of my depth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Active Fighting Subsides in Gaza, but the War Is Not Over, Officials Say
description: Israeli troops have left southern Gaza, and some Palestinians returned to the area, where there was a sense of horror at the scope of destruction.
content: The Israeli military’s departure from southern Gaza over the weekend has left the devastated territory in a state of suspense as active fighting there receded on Monday to its lowest ebb since a brief truce with Hamas in November.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Seeking Answers on Israel and Palestine
description: Responses to an essay that rejected a two-state solution. Also: The U.S. and Israel; the eclipse; end-of-life planning; the church of Trump; the peace sign.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Israel’s withdrawal suggests the war has entered a new phase.
description: The Israeli military’s departure from southern Gaza over the weekend has left the territory without a major battlefield for the first time since a brief truce with Hamas in November, raising hopes that the two sides might reach another cease-fire.
content: The Israeli military’s departure from southern Gaza over the weekend has left the territory without a major battlefield for the first time since a brief truce with Hamas in November, raising hopes that the two sides might reach another cease-fire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emile Ducke, Oleksandr Naselenko and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: When Home Is Now the Front Line
description: As war beat a path through southern and eastern Ukraine, most of the population fled. But other residents have hunkered down, unable — or unwilling — to leave.
content: Two years after Russia launched its full-scale invasion of Ukraine, the hourly artillery duels, airstrikes and pitched fighting in the country’s east and south have turned the more than 600-mile front line into a scarred frontier. Parts of it may be uninhabitable for years, if not decades. Villages and towns are destroyed. Fields are mined. Roads are barely recognizable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: Cash-for-Clients Scheme Lands Ex-Court Clerk and Lawyer in Prison
description: Dionisio Figueroa used his position in Manhattan federal court to steer defendants to Telesforo Del Valle Jr. in a long-running conspiracy, prosecutors said.
content: A former federal court clerk and a New York lawyer who together operated a long-running cash-for-clients bribery scheme were sentenced to prison on Monday, prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Spirit Airlines Will Delay Plane Purchases and Furlough Pilots
description: The low-cost airline, which has been unprofitable for four years, is trying to reduce costs after a federal judge blocked a proposed deal for JetBlue to acquire Spirit.
content: Spirit Airlines said on Monday that it would delay delivery of new Airbus planes and furlough pilots to save money as it seeks to overcome several setbacks, including a blocked merger, engine problems and a lackluster recovery from the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz and Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Vatican Document Casts Gender Change and Fluidity as Threat to Human Dignity
description: The statement is likely to be embraced by conservatives and stir consternation among L.G.B.T.Q. advocates who fear it will be used as a cudgel against transgender people.
content: The Vatican on Monday issued a new document approved by Pope Francis stating that the church believes that gender fluidity and transition surgery, as well as surrogacy, amount to affronts to human dignity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Delger Erdenesanaa
title: PFAS ‘Forever Chemicals’ Are Pervasive in Water Worldwide, Study Finds
description: A global survey found harmful levels even in water samples taken far any obvious source of contamination.
content: They’re in makeup, dental floss and menstrual products. They’re in nonstick pans and takeout food wrappers. Same with rain jackets and firefighting equipment, as well as pesticides and artificial turf on sports fields.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Vadukul
title: Dianne Brill, a 1980s ‘It Girl,’ Makes a Splashy Return
description: “I’m back,” she says at her 66th birthday party. “Maybe not everyone knows it yet, but I am.”
content: When Dianne Brill arrived at the Soho Grand Hotel for her 66th birthday party on Saturday night, she did so with the same sense of spectacle that made her an icon of Manhattan nightlife in the 1980s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Containers Are Being Removed From Ship That Hit Key Bridge
description: Workers are unloading the 4,700 containers on the ship, a crucial step in moving the vessel and reopening the channel in the Port of Baltimore.
content: Workers on Sunday began removing containers from the giant cargo vessel that remains pinned under the metal remains of Baltimore’s Key Bridge, nearly two weeks after the ship struck the bridge and caused it to collapse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman, Jonathan Swan and Michael Gold
title: Trump Says Abortion Restrictions Should Be Left to the States
description: After months of mixed signals, Donald Trump said that whatever states decide “must be the law of the land,” adding that he was “strongly in favor of exceptions for rape, incest and life of the mother.”
content: Former President Donald J. Trump said in a video statement on Monday that abortion rights should be left up to the states, remarks that came after months of mixed signals on an issue that he and his advisers have worried could cost him dearly in the election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eli Saslow and Erin Schaff
title: Dr. Bob, 75, Knows Aging’s Toll. He Wonders if Biden and Trump Do.
description: Dr. Bob Ross cares for the aging residents of Ortonville, Minn, even as he wonders whether he, and the presidential candidates, are up to all their tasks.
content: He had become the local expert on what he called the “unwanted side effects of old age,” so Dr. Bob Ross, 75, rubbed arthritis cream onto his hands and walked into an exam room to see his seventh elderly patient of the day. He had been a doctor in the remote town of Ortonville, Minn., for nearly five decades, caring for most of its 2,000 residents as he aged alongside them. He delivered their children, performed their high school physicals, tended to their workplace injuries and now specialized in treating the wide-ranging symptoms of what it meant to grow old in America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judson Jones
title: Solar Eclipse Could Make Some Clouds Perform a Disappearing Act
description: A recent study found that cumulus clouds, the small cotton ball-like ones typical for a sunny day, can dissipate once an eclipse begins. But if the skies are overcast, your view could still be obstructed.
content: As the eclipse begins, some view-blocking clouds could actually disappear. A recent study found that after 15 percent of the sun becomes obscured, cumulus clouds, the small cotton ball-like ones typical for a sunny day, can dissipate. Even if you are outside the path of totality, watch what happens to the clouds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Santul Nerkar and J. Edward Moreno
title: Cities in the eclipse’s path are getting an economic ‘shot in the arm.’
description: Millions of tourists trying to experience the totality could bolster smaller economies across North America.
content: A vast swath of North America will soon be plunged into darkness. Though momentary, the total solar eclipse on Monday has already proved lucrative.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yonette Joseph and Leily Nikounazar
title: Iran Pardons 4 Environmental Activists to Commemorate Eid al-Fitr, Lawyer Says
description: Two have been freed so far, state media said. They were among eight arrested in 2018 on charges of spying, which they have denied.
content: Iran has pardoned and begun freeing four environmental activists who spent several years in prison on espionage charges, Iranian state media said on Monday. The pardons were granted to commemorate Eid al-Fitr, the Islamic holiday celebrated at the end of Ramadan, according to their lawyer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: The Eclipse Brought Darkness and Fascination
description: Also, Donald Trump said abortion limits should be decided by states. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
content: In an awe-inspiring cosmic coincidence, the moon and sun perfectly aligned this afternoon, producing a total solar eclipse visible across North America. The moon’s shadow plunged daylight into darkness, carving a path from Mexico, up to Maine and into Canada. We took lots of photos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marlise Simons
title: Nicaragua Takes Germany to Court Over Supplying Arms to Israel
description: A new case before the International Court of Justice argues that the German government is furthering genocide in the Gaza war.
content: Nicaragua, a longstanding supporter of the Palestinian cause, is broadening the legal battle over the Gaza conflict at the International Court of Justice by bringing a case against Germany, a major supplier of arms to Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kliff
title: Paying Off People’s Medical Debt Has Little Impact on Their Lives, Study Finds
description: A nonprofit group called R.I.P. Medical Debt has relieved Americans of $11 billion in hospital bills. But that did not improve their mental health or their credit scores, a study found.
content: Over the past decade, R.I.P. Medical Debt has grown from a tiny nonprofit group that received less than $3,000 in donations to a multimillion-dollar force in health care philanthropy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Monday Briefing
description: Israel says it withdrew troops from southern Gaza.
content: The Israeli military said that it had withdrawn a division of ground troops from the southern Gaza Strip.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Jerry Grote, Stalwart Mets Catcher on ’69 Championship Team, Dies at 81
description: Known for his field savvy and his powerful arm, he helped propel the New York Mets through their storied 1969 World Series run.
content: Jerry Grote, who was among the National League’s leading catchers of his time and guided the pitching staff that propelled the New York Mets to their astonishing 1969 World Series championship, died on Sunday in Austin, Texas. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: Missouri Governor Denies Clemency for Death Row Inmate Who Got Support From Guards
description: Dozens of correctional workers urged Gov. Mike Parson to commute the death sentence of Brian Dorsey, who pleaded guilty in the murders of Ben and Sarah Bonnie.
content: Mike Parson, the governor of Missouri, said on Monday that he would not commute the death sentence of Brian Dorsey, who pleaded guilty to murdering Ben and Sarah Bonnie in 2006 and is scheduled to be executed on Tuesday unless the courts intervene.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Tuesday Briefing: A Total Solar Eclipse
description: Also, the Vatican said gender changes amount to an affront.
content: Millions of people across North America gathered outside yesterday to behold the disorienting, disquieting wonder of darkness in the daytime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Moskin
title: Yes, You Can Wash Cast Iron: 5 Big Kitchen Myths, Debunked
description: A veteran food journalist digs into some common misconceptions about salting pasta water, browning meat and more.
content: Food myths come from many sources, and American cooks (including me) have swallowed lots of them. Some of them used to be truths, like the notion that you should eat oysters only in “R” months (before refrigeration, shellfish were safer to eat in the winter). Some come from restaurant kitchens, like the rule against washing mushrooms. (When you’re ready to use them, it’s perfectly fine to rinse off the dirt. Just don’t store them after washing; they will spoil once wet.) And some just derive from superstition, like the idea that brown eggs are healthier than white ones. (They are identical inside the shell; the color is determined by the hen’s feathers.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Virgil Abloh’s Legacy Is About to Get Louder
description: Shannon Abloh and the Fashion Scholarship Fund unveil a new plan.
content: Many companies, including fashion companies, may be going silent about their diversity, equity and inclusion initiatives in the face of political change. The last round of major designer appointments may not have included a single creative director of color. But at least one group is doubling down on its commitment to broadening the style-talent pipeline.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: Do You Know These Novels Driven by Climate Change?
description: Try this short quiz on recent fiction that follows characters dealing with a turbulent world.
content: Try this short quiz on recent fiction that follows characters dealing with a turbulent world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: The Eclipse Across North America
description: What people in the path of totality were seeing and saying as the eclipse unfolded across the continent.
content: What people in the path of totality were seeing and saying as the eclipse unfolded across the continent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By K.K. Rebecca Lai and William B. Davis
title: See the Total Solar Eclipse’s Shadow From Space
description: An American weather satellite is capturing the movement of the moon’s shadow across North America during the total eclipse of the sun on Monday.
content: An American weather satellite is capturing the movement of the moon’s shadow across North America during the total eclipse of the sun on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angelo Fichera
title: The Method Behind Trump’s Mistruths
description: A close examination of every public word from the former president during a crucial week of his campaign.
content: A close examination of every public word from the former president during a crucial week of his campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Biden Announces New Plan for Student Debt Relief
description: President Biden announced a large-scale effort to help pay off federal student loans for more than 20 million borrowers.
content: President Biden announced a large-scale effort to help pay off federal student loans for more than 20 million borrowers.
